message:
No; "async" doesn't mean "run on another thread".

The way it would work is like this:  
- TestAsyncCall calls DoSomethingAsync.  
- DoSomethingAsync calls Task.Delay and awaits the task it returned. This causes DoSomethingAsync to return an incomplete task.  
- TestAsyncCall stores that incomplete task into TaskResult1 and invokes DoSomething.  
- DoSomething returns "synch" to TestAsyncCall.  
- TestAsyncCall stores that string into Result2.  
- TestAsyncCall awaits the task returned from DoSomethingAsync. This causes TestAsyncCall to return to its caller.

some time later...  
- The task returned from Task.Delay completes.  
- DoSomethingAsync resumes executing. It may be on the same thread or a different thread, depending on the context that was captured by its await (see my post on this page for details).  
- DoSomethingAsync completes its task with the value "asynch".  
- TestAsyncCall resumes executing. Again, it may or may not be on the same thread.
